name: Assassin’s Creed® Liberation HD
description: Introducing Assassin’s Creed® Liberation HD, the striking chapter of the pre-American Revolution Assassin’s Creed saga which arrives for the first time on HD consoles and PC. With improved gameplay, a deeper story, and HD graphics, Liberation is an immersive and full Assassin’s Creed experience.The year is 1765.

reviews.review_text: Originally, this game was made as an exclusive title for the Playstation Vita, but was later ported to other systems, like the PC. Yes, it's a port, and it shows.  It's supposed to be a HD game, but don't get fooled by that. Though the graphics are not ugly, there's loads of examples of low res textures everywhere. But the worst part, is that the FPS seems to be locked at some very low value, which gets VERY straining on the eyes. And that's my #1 issue with this game, it's painful to play it.  The new feature that makes this game different from other AC games, is that the main protaganist can change between 3 different 'roles', each with a suitable outfit for that role. The roles are Lady, Slave and Assassin. When playing a certain role, there are restrictions to what you can do, or extra things that role can that no one else can. For example, as a Slave, you can pick up crates and walk past guards unnoticed, if you don't take too long.  Sounds interesting? Well it isn't. It's a good idea that ends up being a barrier, and restricts you.  Else it's just more of the same. This game is often considered as a standalone addition to AC3, so if you've played that one, you already know a lot about what you're getting. Though it isn't nowhere near the size of AC3.  The low FPS is the main reason I'm not recommending the game. But apart from that, the rest is pretty much 'meh...' and not really worth spending much money on. If you're still interested, pick it up on sale, do not buy it at full price.

I recommend the game but with a huge caveat: of all the Assassin's Creed games I've played, this is by far the most buggy. Here's the bugs I spotted without even searching for them in my 31 hour play through: -Game controls locked up repeatedly when pressing the wrong button after B when being attacked by a wild cat. -Canoes about 30-50 feet floating in mid-air (unsuable). Restart game required. -Mounting and dismounting canoes often is more difficult than it should be. -The mission where you are supposed to scout out the three camps, I was a slave and looted the chests without alerting the guards. The subesequent mission where you are supposed to loot the chests therefore breaks because 2 out of 3 are still in looted condition. I have yet to find a way to replay the mission to reset the chests. -Game will only accept input from keyboard+mouse or controller at once; it does not accept both; moreover, when my wireless controller turns off and I turn it back on, the game switches to and stays in keyboard+mouse mode instead of going back to controller. -I've had a flickery static effect that usually only happens on level transitions keep happening over and over again. I had to restart the game because it was driving me batty. -When exiting combat and sometimes looting, the look controls often lock up while it is finishing a painstakingly long animation. Very annoying. -Typo on Lady Persona page. -It takes too long to open/close map/menu. When are developers going to learn to stop animating menu entry/exit?  I also have one general complaint that applies to Assassin's Creed III as well: get rid of or automate the trade system. It feels like work to use it which is a lot like Mass Effect 2's planet probing.  Despite all of that, I still recommend the game and the reason why is simple: it's better than Assassin's Creed III. Not as long, not as varied, and no manning the helm of a ship, but the story in this game was actually enjoyable and the new mechanic of personas and the addition of the whip was a nice change. Granted, if you're tired of Assassin's Creed gameplay, especially Assassin's Creed III, avoid this game. If you like Assassin's Creed despite this title's particularlly glaring shortcomings, by all means grab it, play it, and enjoy it.

originally released as a tie-in for ACIII on Vita, this remastered edition of Liberation is pretty great, but not without it's flaws. it's ubisoft open-world formula at it's most restrained and very slimmed down. however, some things are too slimmed down.   the biggest let down, in my opinion, is the story and characters. i imagine that because the game was originally designed for a portable system and the audience that comes with it (ie. pick up and play for 10 minutes at a time), the concept had to reflect that and so a LOT of plot points and characters aren't well-developed.   that being said, it's still really cool to play AC with a rad as hell lady protag in a scenario that is often avoided by games. def recommanded on sale.

On the downside, the plot is gibberish, the port from the Vita leaves it looking super-ugly, and the gameplay is often parcelled out in lamentably small portions. Plus, the 'strategic' elements are utterly pointless. Overall, I felt a bit disappointed, but you don't often get to play a black French woman in a game, so it was interesting for that at least.

I wasn't really sure what to expect from this game going in. The PS Vita version got some pretty mixed reviews, so I was skeptical. Ultimately, Assassin's Creed: Liberation HD won me over. It's pretty short compared to the main Assassin's Creed games, but for only $20 it's ultimately a solid deal. The game plays mostly like Assassin's Creed 3, with the exception of the cool, new kill chain feature, which allows you to quickly target up to 3 enemies at once and kill them all in quick succession. It's fun. There's also a new take on the notoriety system called personas. Aveline, the game's protagonist, may change between 3 outfits that change how guards treat her. The standard Assassin getup allows for full mobility and equipment usage, but you always have your notoriety meter at least a quarter filled. Her slave disguise also allows free-running, but she's restricted to blow darts, her hidden blade, and a machete. She can sneak right into restricted areas as long as she looks like she's working, but socially unacceptable actions carry a much higher noteriety penalty than usual. Aveline's Lady persona, aside from making her look pretty attractive, makes her nearly impossible to discover in restricted areas, but the dress she is wearing prevents her from climbing at all, and allows her to move on foot at a jog at the fastest. She is also limited to just her hidden blade and a parasol gun. It was an interesting new idea that was mostly successful, but could have used a bit more freedom and variety in practice.   On the story side of things, the game is pretty irrelevant. I couldn't help but often question why Aveline was going through any of the scenarios I was playing. There's no sense of urgency to the game that drives the plot forward, unlike the main series. Visually, the game is pretty impressive. Again it's roughly on the same level as Assassin's Creed 3 in that regard. The game world itself is a decent size. Over the course of the game, you visit New Orleans, the Lousiana bayou, and Chichén Itzá: a templar controlled colony in Mexico. New Orelans is similar in size to AC3's Boston, while being a fair bit more colorful and varied. The Bayou is dwarfed by the Frontier, but it's still farily expansive and takes some time to fully explore. Overall, If you're looking for a little bit more Assassin's Creed to tide you over while you wait for Unity, Liberation is a worthwhile buy.

I got this after completing the Ezio trilogy, thinking nothing could top how much I liked them. This absolutely does. It runs 100x smoother, has more longevity, and above all, feels more realistic. I've thought time and time again that Ezio (and the other assassins) stick out like sore thumbs in their robes, and finally, it got addressed. Aveline can dress as a Lady, to blend with the elite crowd and charm/bribe guards into letting her in restricted areas. She can dress as a Slave, to blend with other workers and get in to places only slaves would be allowed, as well as being able to free run and climb in this persona. And thirdly, we can dress as an Assassin, but the attire looks more pirate/sailer in my opinion. The only downside is that in Assassin persona, you're always slightly notorious.   Another issue I've had with previous AC's is that you can't climb trees...the one thing even most regular people could climb. Aveline not only climbs trees, but can take advantage of hanging vines to swing from tree to tree. You also get a whip some 1/4 way in to swing from things with, and to catch and drag back enemies that might be running from you.   There are plenty of side missions, a large amount specific to each persona, which means you can switch as you please to do missions you're in the mood for. You make money in Liberation by using the ship trading system, which is pretty fun and easy to use.   My only qualm with this game is that it uses the newer fighting system, and I find it a bit player unfriendly.

EDIT: The latest patch appears to have fixed my initial control issues in my original negative review.   Other reviews cover the plot better than I can at this time. I've only been able to play about an hour of the game.  From my limited perspective, the game appears to work as any Assassin's Creed game should. Avoid detection, blend into the crowd, etc etc. The concept of switching clothing seems awesome at first, but I've all ready found pretty early in the game that this doesn't seem executed well.   The limitations of, say, the Slave Girl versus The Asassin make sense story wise, but makes for awkward play. I believe a different reviewer pointed out s/he would just wear whatever Aveline happened to be wearing at the time to get the job done. It's this disjointed execution of limitations that give rise to a more complicated combat system, but not really depth. If one were to pick at this thread a little more, it would seem odd how an assassin would lose access to tools simply because the clothing was different. Assassins are assassins regardless of their garb. I think this observation is part of the blocky combat issue noted by other reviewers. In other words, Slave Girl should be as effective as The Assassin and vice versus, but this is not the case.  It's still early for me in the game, and so for now, I will recommend the game because I'm enjoying it. If the game somehow completely breaks for me, I will note it here and change my recommendation if I feel its warranted.

As like all other Assassin Creeds it sets out to tell you a great story and it accomplishes that, gameplay and mechanics stay true.   I can only really recommend this to die hard assassin creed fans, looking for a fix between mainstream releases. It's brings a couple new ideas to the table, but nothing absolutely amazing. The story like always is great, but as a change of pace it features a female lead. All in all give it shot and show Aveline the spotlight she deserves

Based on the same gameplay mechanics as AC3, this game achieves more good than it predecessor. Even though it is a ported game.   Disguises are really what makes the game more stylish, diverse and stealthy. Having played Hitman for the first time just recently, I realised how much a disguise can mean. And here, to be able to change is what the game really needs. Each disguise has different tailor variant, different weapons (sometimes not ownable by other personas), different blending, different notoriety. It’s a pity that by now this was only implemented in this game.   Fixed convoys and trade system. Now it calls for investments and regular check ups.   Underwater missions are really good and if you play the games chronologically, this will come before marvelous diving missions from AC4BF (technically, here they tested it out, the same they did woth Aquila in AC3).  Of course, since the game was small, the city is smaller, the ‘Frontier’ (here – Bayou) is smaller, the gameplay time is less, but it good since you don’t grow tired of it.  One of the most correct games in all the franchise, totally recommend it.

What we have here is a failure to communicate... with the simulation timer.  The story in Assassin's Creed: Liberation HD is incredible, I honestly don't understand how they started it off at such a low price originally. The persona (character) options also make for an interesting, realistic experience.  The problem is the simulation timing is off. There is a dizzying, herky-jerky, pause every other second, almost as if the frames are being rendered faster than the game mechanics can react. Every minute or two, it gets so backed up that it even loses input response. Many times I had my kill or jump timed perfectly, only to have the controller become unresponsive momentarily, leaving me able to do nothing but watch Aveline's ragdoll corpse jostle about.  It is worth noting that the story kept me playing all the way through, but it was only my 30 years out of 35 in gaming experience that kept me from hurling up my lunch evertime I played. Suffice it to say, a controller was nearly laid to rest from the frustration of this unlikely game engine glitch.  And before you blame my hardware... An MSI GT70-2PE Dominator Pro, with its NVidia 880 and 8GB of Video RAM, should be able to hand this 1 year older game, with the ease of pilfering confectionary treats from a prepubescent child (like taking candy from a baby).  Addendum (One week later): Having completed the game, I can guarrantee that the story is wonderfull, however the game suffers from egregious annoyances such as enemies attacking before they can be targetted, attacks from literally invisible enemies, random hangs when reloading guns, random roof edges in open, flat areas, and the previously mentioned severe lack of smooth simulation timing. These annoyances continue throughout the game.

Going into Liberation, I knew three things: that it was a port from the Vita, that it took place at the same time as AC3, and that it had a female protagonist. I had never played an Assassin's Creed game seriously before this one - I dabbled about a bit with Assassin's Creed II, but stopped playing after I found Ezio and Desmond to be thoroughly boring and unlikeable. Since this game was supposedly not tied into all the silly meta-narrative and didn't include a single appearance of Desmond or cartoonishly-evil Abstergo employees, I figured it was as good a time as any to stop laughing at the series from afar and play one of these games myself to see what all the fuss was about. Plus, it was five bucks on sale - what have I got to lose?  As it turns out, I ended up enjoying myself. A lot. More than I thought I would, and more than I was expecting based on the reviews it's been getting. The parkour system, even though it's been used as the framework for this series since the start, is still tons of fun, and I often just fire up this game sometimes and run around just to relax myself. Every animation is incredibly fluid and seamless - with just the push of a button, Aveline can scale wooden buildings, swing around a tree trunk as she runs across its branches, use lampposts and hanging signs as stepping stones to cross a street ten feet below you...it's all so much fun to watch and it's even more fun to be the one doing it. Sure, there are times where you can't grab a ledge you can clearly reach (the Bayou in particular is a bad offender in this regard) but for the most part, the free-running is sublime.  As the first female Assassin, and thanks to both her African and French heritage, Aveline is capable of changing between different personas with nothing more than a dressing chamber, each with a different set of strengths and weaknesses. The default Assassin persona is always at least a little notorious, but it's the best suited for combat and can use any and all weapons. The Slave persona limits the weapons and health, but allows you to blend in with groups of slaves - and since this is set during the American Revolution, slaves are in no short supply. The Lady persona has a massive hat and dress that allows Aveline to be seen as a respectable member of the nobility, but the hem of the skirt makes it impossible to do any kind of free-running and makes combat incredibly difficult. Each one is used throughout the story at different times, and all feel well-balanced and rounded - it's a great example of a game telling a story through it's mechanics alone.  Combat, however, is a different story. Enemies are really fickle and trigger happy, and guards will be more than willing to fire a musket as soon as you come within line of sight. And when you get a high enough notoriety, they practically send the whole force after you - and if you're in the Lady persona with just a hidden blade and no smoke bombs, you're gonna have a bad time. There are plenty of ways to approach an encounter, however - the hidden blade is the standard Assassin weapon of choice, but Aveline also has access to swords, axes, slave tools, guns, and assorted gizmos to work with in combat. Not all weapons are available for all personas, of course - you can't swing around an obsidian axe as a lowly slave, for instance - but as long as you keep on top of upgrades and stay stocked up on supplies, you'll have everything you need to get out of a situation alive. Most of the challenge in combat comes from timing your counters to do special instant-kill moves - it's a quick-timed event, but the animations look REALLY good.  Overall, I'm having a lot of fun with Liberation. It's substantial enough that I can play it for fifteen minute bursts to ease some stress in between classes with free-running and trading, but still engrossing enough that I can sit down and play it for hours on end. If all Assassin's Creed games are like this one, then I can see why people are getting tired of it after a while - but as for me, it's easily becoming one of my favorite games that I played this year.

When I first found out about Liberation, I was upset that it wasn't going to be available on anything but the PS Vita. Now that it's out on other platforms I'm even more convinced it should have been released like this at the start. Liberation is a great addition to the franchise. Aveline's story is great and compelling and pretty nifty how it ties in with Assassin's Creed 3. I believe it should be considered a part of the series among the rest, not just an add-on.

Well - I must say I was a little scared at first - mostly because this game is a port from mobile devices. I tried such game before - unfamous 'Deus Ex: The Fall' which... let's just say wasn't good. So this time I didn't expect to much from the beginning. But - I was positively suprised. The game is very nice. It is somewhat simplified comparing to AC 3 for example, but still pack a ton of fun. I liked the idea of persona changing especially, which allows the player to turn into three very different persons, with different skill and abilities - almost at will. And three different personas means at least three different ways to handle some quests (some, as the others are reserved for one persona only). Also - making the main character a female gives this game some different, unique feel... Finally, the lengh of the game is just all right - not to much (it is not a 'main line' game after all) and not to little (again comparing to only 2-3 hours long 'Deus Ex: The Fall'...). Definately something worth playing !

Maybe I am biased in writing this review, being a big fan of the Assassin's Creed franchise.  But I really believe this is a truly fun game to play, even for someone who 'accidentally' stumbles upon this game, never having played an earlier iteration of the game.  It takes about 20 hours to complete the game with 100% syncronization, which is more than adequate for the price required.  The graphics are better than would be expected for a Vita port. The ambience is not so engaging as previous games, due to the game being a conversion from the console, and the music is quite repetitive.  Still, as stated above, it is fun to play and it is a fine addition to your library of games.

If you are a big Assassin's Creed fan (AC) you should play this (wait until it's on sale). If not, you should probably skip it. The fact that this is a port from a portable game is evident. The...production value is not as high as it is in other AC games. The voice acting and cutscenes are not great. The framerate also seems to be deliverately capped in some areas as 30 FPS and many of the missions are less than inspired. After the first hour, however, I thought the game really takes off.   I found Aveline to be the most likeable AC protagonist outside of Ezio (haven't played Unity or Syndicate). It's also nice to see a great, awesome female protagonist that isn't a sex object.  This game is much shorter than other AC games, which might actually be a good thing.
